awd_titl_txt: ADVANCE Catalyst: Gender and Racial Equity in the STEM Faculty at UMass Boston
awd_abstract_narration:
University of Massachusetts, Boston (UMB) will implement an ADVANCE Catalyst project to conduct an institutional self-assessment to understand the status of women faculty in STEM disciplines on the main campus.  The three goals for the project are: 1) examining the systemic barriers and facilitators of gender and racial equity among STEM faculty through an intersectional lens in the realms of hiring, tenure, promotion, differential service burdens, and faculty sense of belonging, 2) piloting a strategy to address the systemic causes of gender and racial inequities for faculty, and 3) empowering faculty and administrators to promote gender and racial equity.  The project will focus on the intersections of faculty gender, race/ethnicity, sexual orientation, different abilities, family status, and faculty appointment type and rank.
This two-year project will prepare the university for future data collection and data analyses of faculty equity which can be used by institutional leadership to inform decision-making.  The Catalyst work will also prepare the institution to implement evidence-based strategies to enhance the university climate for all faculty which will be outlined in a five-year faculty equity strategic plan that will be produced as part of this project.   
The NSF ADVANCE program is designed to foster gender equity through a focus on the identification and elimination of organizational barriers that impede the full participation and advancement of diverse faculty in academic institutions.  Organizational barriers that inhibit equity may exist in policies, processes, practices, and the organizational culture and climate.  ADVANCE "Catalyst" awards provide support for institutional equity assessments and the development of five-year faculty equity strategic plans at an academic, non-profit institution of higher education.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
The National Science Foundation funded a three-year ADVANCE Catalyst grant (2019-2022) for an institutional self-assessment at UMass Boston to focus on gender and racial equity among science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) faculty through a lens of intersectionality (ADVANCE Catalyst Gender and Racial Equity in the STEM Faculty at UMass Boston). The project team conducted a case study focusing on hiring, tenure, promotion, research, teaching, service, faculty communities and affinity groups, and sense of belonging among STEM faculty. 

Project activities included the collection and analysis of individual and focus group interview data with STEM faculty and administrators (department chairs, associate deans, deans, union leaders, provost, and chancellor), the review of institutional documents and data, and a pilot study of faculty affinity groups. Findings identified both barriers to and facilitators of gender and racial equity in the STEM faculty at the university. Key barriers include inequities in service; the inadequate recognition of community-engaged research; the undervaluation of faculty caring work; weak support systems for research; faculty experiences with discrimination; departmental variation in focus on equity and diversity in hiring, promotion, and tenure; and challenges unique to the non-tenure-track faculty experience. Major facilitators of equity were grounded in the strength of faculty affinity groups and communities; well-developed supports for teaching; faculty commitment to the university's mission of equity and diverse student population; and strengths of equity-minded departmental values and practices in hiring, tenure, and promotion. Findings also showed the differential impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic on faculty, shaping the experiences of faculty of color and women faculty in STEM in large measure and in some ways that will multiply toward the future.

Key outcomes include the UMass Boston ADVANCE Catalyst report detailing findings and recommendations for the university community, two conference papers presented at the 2022 annual meeting of the Association for the Study of Higher Education, and major contributions based on ADVANCE Catalyst findings to the university's 10-Year Strategic Plan, For the Times.

The project team presented the following recommendations:

Address communication and culture challenges by:

  • Creating spaces for open communication that include faculty and administrators at all levels to identify and address structures that maintain inequities and to enhance mechanisms that have been proven effective in overcoming inequities, and
  • Elevating and intentionally recognizing departmental policies, practices, and processes that effectively support women and faculty of color.

Build community by:

  • Recognizing and enhancing spaces that support sense of belonging for faculty who identify as members of minoritized and historically marginalized communities, and
  • Reviewing departmental norms and practices in relation to inclusivity for NTT faculty and change policies that cement these inequities.

Improve hiring, retention, and promotion practices by:

  • Generating greater clarity of expectations about what counts as research, teaching, and service,
  • Defining community-engaged work, particularly community-engaged research, and caring work and recognize their value to the university by establishing explicit and intentional reward systems in personnel processes, and
  • Implementing implicit bias training for hiring and personnel processes and creating accountability systems for review and assessment of progress toward reducing inequities.

Increase professional development support for faculty by:

  • Nurturing specific supports that faculty have identified as critical to their success and well-being, and
  • Developing and strengthening support systems that meet the research-related needs of faculty.

Embrace a long-range view of the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic and recalibrate the evaluation of faculty work.

Overall, the project has facilitated widespread awareness of barriers to and facilitators of gender and racial equity in the STEM faculty at UMass Boston and has led to continuining discussions of implementing the recommendations.
